The Ministry of Health has received unverified reports regarding adverse events arising from the recent polio vaccination campaign. Investigations are ongoing, and a formal statement will be issued in due course. We discourage members of the public from spreading rumors and

PRESS STATEMENT ON THE POLIO VACCINATION CAMPAIGN

From October 2-6, 2024, the Ministry of Health vaccinated 3,712,323 children under ten across nine counties, following the detection of poliovirus in parts of Kenya and Uganda. https://t.co/QuaxSQzO0c

📢 The Ministry of Health, in collaboration with county governments and partners (@UNICEFKenya & @WHO) will conduct the second round of polio vaccination campaigns from Saturday, 9th Nov to Wednesday, 13th Nov 2024, in 9 high-risk counties. All eligible children will receive the https://t.co/MHwqMrSJGV

The second round of the nationwide polio vaccination campaign to protect children kicked off today. In Nairobi County, a mini launch for Lang’ata Subcounty was held at Jinnah Clinic, South C Ward, with support from key stakeholders, including representatives from the Nairobi https://t.co/Lf6zzJe5As
PRESS STATEMENT ON CONTINUING POLIO CAMPAIGN https://t.co/eYMWottdEN

We’re committed to a polio-free Kenya! Let’s achieve high vaccination coverage to eradicate polio for good. Join the second round of the polio vaccination campaign from Nov 9-13 to protect every child. #EndPolioKE #VaccinesSaveLives https://t.co/zfA1mQcT6q

All Kenyan children under the age of 5 years are expected to be up to date with childhood vaccines where they receive Polio vaccine at birth, 6 weeks, 10 weeks, and 14 weeks as per the routine immunization schedule. In the event of an outbreak, the polio vaccine is given to all https://t.co/HKxrpsgrAm
Vaccines save lives. Polio is disabling. We fully support this campaign to ensure all children are protected. – Dr. Supa Tunje, Chair, Kenya Paediatric Association https://t.co/MgRESosoKg

The Ministry of Health assures the public, the Polio vaccine is safe and... https://t.co/5x7V4D2yHQ via @YouTube

The Ministry of Health assures all vaccines, including the polio vaccine, are safe and effective in shielding our children from preventable diseases. Vaccines prompt the immune system to fight infections, and while mild side effects may happen, they usually resolve quickly. https://t.co/GYqmo7Ukkj

The polio vaccination campaign is here to protect our children’s future! From November 9th to 13th, 2024, make sure your child is vaccinated in any of these high-risk counties: Busia, Bungoma, Trans-Nzoia, West Pokot, Turkana, Nairobi, Kiambu, Machakos, and Kajiado. “How can I tell if my child is having a bad reaction to the vaccine?”

Some of the common side effects may include rash, fever, irritability, vomiting, fatigue, diarrhea, headaches or muscle pain. These are mild reactions as the #polio vaccine is SAFE and approved by the @WHO https://t.co/HLRmBO5N6i

Your child deserves protection from polio. If you’re in Busia, Bungoma, Trans-Nzoia, West Pokot, Turkana, Nairobi, Kiambu, Machakos, or Kajiado, our dedicated vaccinators are going door-to-door to ensure every child receives this vital vaccine.
